title: Thursday, 7th December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Oh, hey.

BE11:02am

Let's kick off with some genetically mutated rats.

BE11:03am

Genetically mutated rats could be released into Britain to help tackle the growing problem with rodents, Edinburgh University has said.

11:02 am
BE11:03am

That's as per the Telegraph: http://www.telegra...tain-solve-rodent/

BE11:03am

The technology uses the DNA editing technique called Crispr, a natural process by which bacteria fight off viruses by snipping away at their DNA.

BE11:03am

Crispr's "a natural process"? ... yeah, ish.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

By the way, Crispr's Wiki page is absolutely bloody amazing and, to me, largely incomprehensible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CRISPR

BE11:04am

Professor Bruce Whitelaw, of the University of Edinburgh’s Roslin Institute, where Dolly the Sheep was created, said: “For the first time we have the makings of technology that could reduce or eliminate a pest population in a humane and species-specific manner.
“Crispr is perhaps the most exciting tool that has ever hit biology, and it is a fantastic tool for us to pull apart the function of genes and how the animal or plant functions.
"It’s time to explore what this technology can do.”

BE11:05am

Have I mentioned I once worked in the print room of the Roslin Institute?

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Summer job. Making copies of the research for distribution and archiving.

BE11:05am

I was absolutely hopeless at it. Often got the pages mixed up.

BE11:05am

Could never keep track of which printer to feed or which binder to use.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

But no-one ever seemed to notice, though.

BE11:05am

Let's hope they don't genetically mutate too many rats based on the archive I had a hand in.

undefined
11:06 am
BE11:06am

And so, from genetically mutated rats to GVC.

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 169.00, up 33.3 (+24.54%), High: 175.70, Low: 165.00, Volume: 34.82m
BE11:06am

They've managed to get a statement out before it leaked this time!

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Albeit it's only a 2.6,

BE11:08am

Gist here is that Ladbrokes Coral and GVC say they have had "detailed" discussions about a combination.

BE11:08am

That would've been an accurate statement at any point in the past two or three years, of course, but moving on .....

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Offer works as 32.7p in cash and 0.141 ordinary GVC shares

BE11:09am

Plus a 42.8p kicker depending on where the roulette machine review lands up.

BE11:09am

The key question to all this is, of course: why's GVC in such a hurry?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

We know the GVC model. It's to take revenue from unregulated markets and use it to buy revenue from regulated markets. And, like a prehistoric shark, it's a model that has to keep moving forward otherwise it drowns.

BE11:11am

Still, its seems curious that GVC would rather build this complicated bid structure rather than hold for a couple of months for certainty on the FOBT review.

BE11:12am

Let's cut to Barclays for the pros and cons, at least in terms of Ladbrokes shareholders.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

i) Geographic diversification (diversifying LCL’s c. 85% revenue exposure to the UK and thus reducing regulatory risk in the UK), ii) Scale (scale is one of the most important attributes for online gambling companies improving ROIC in the long run), iii) Technology (LCL will have access to GVC’s proprietary technology which ultimately means the proposed combined entity would reduce exposure to revenue-share agreements with software providers), iv) Synergies (the cost synergies generated by the PPB deal were £65m and for Ladbrokes Coral it was £150m - it seems logical to consider this a useful range).

BE11:12am

Those are the pros ......

BE11:12am

These are the cons .....

11:12 am
BE11:12am

i) The biggest risk is that the technology integration reduces the focus on new product development and thus impacts growth in the core online division. Ladbrokes.com is current losing UK market share (wagering -9% for the last 4 months). Set against this backdrop, we believe a large scale technology integration will be fraught with potential challenges. We rate the management team of LCL highly, and note that GVC has been an acquisition engine in recent years (buying bwin and Sportingbet for example) so is aware of how to integrate businesses well. ii) Key staff departures. iii) Multiple brands in multiple countries: will brand need to be removed?

BE11:13am

Should note as a sidebar that Playtech's being sold.

Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 796.50, down 49.5 (-5.85%), High: 847.50, Low: 776.00, Volume: 2.03m
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Kenny Alexander was a bit evasive on the conference call about whether GVC would dump Playtech entirely. Notes that they have a contract ......

BE11:15am

Saying the deal would give Playtech "opportunities", and that he "will have a discussion with Mor and hopefully we can work out something."

BE11:15am

Mor being Mor Weizer, Playtech chief.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, back to the point.

BE11:15am

Here's Davy

BE11:16am

The one possible question with respect to the deal is the relative share of the enlarged group. The proposed offer would give LCL shareholders a 46.5% share of the combined entity with GVC shareholders getting a 53.5% share. While the regulatory risk attached to LCL is well understood by the market, we wonder whether the same can be said for GVC. The premium will very
likely mean that LCL holders will be happy to support this deal but they should just be mindful of paying a high multiple for higher risk earnings streams. Overall though, a smart deal for both sides.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

This kicker thing ....

BE11:16am

— At £2 staking limit, the CVR would be worth 0p.
— At £20 staking limit, the CVR would be worth 30.3p.
— At £50 staking limit, the CVR would be worth 42.8p

BE11:18am

Can't ever remember a bid being structured this way before. Feels ... tricksy?

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Citi incoming.

BE11:18am

We have previously commented that we think a £20-£30 outcome in the triennial review is realistic, pointing to a tighter range for the CVR of 30.3p-40.4p. We are also mindful that the GVC equity would also absorb some of the triennial risk.

BE11:19am

GVC note the possible offer would result in "material synergies" which they would quantify in any announcement of a firm intention to make an offer. We have previously pointed to potentially substantial savings from moving LCL’s online business to the proprietary GVC platform. We also reference €125m of synergies in the GVC/BWIN merger and £150m of synergies in the more recent Ladbrokes/Coral merger as possible benchmarks. Given that our bear case in the triennial review was a loss of £110m of EBIT then it is clear that synergies could offset this. GVC believe the transaction to be double digit EPS accretive from the first full year post-completion following all expected Triennial outcomes including a £2 stake, while the combined group ND/EBITDA would not exceed 3.0x

11:20 am
BE11:20am

And Shore .......

BE11:20am

We have long argued that under a £20 scenario fair value was between 180p and 200p given the significant Coral merger synergies and re-rating opportunities so there appears little premium in the offer price. However, set against this a somewhat underpins the price against the triennial review whilst investors will get access to the potential additional synergies (capitalise £100m synergies at 10x would equate to a further 25p per Ladbrokes Coral share. We retain a BUY stance on Ladbrokes Coral.

Elsewhere, we would highlight Playtech^ (PTEC: Buy at 850p). At this stage we are uncertain our the potential impact on one of its most important licensees although note its stake in Ladbrokes Coral is worth approaching 80p per share.

BE11:21am

Anyway, let's assume for a moment that this gets done.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We've been banging on for a very long time about sector consolidation post the Triennial ......

BE11:24am

..... Ladbrokes-GVC doesn't really change much in terms of the high street. As we say above, it's a "legitimising revenue" argument, mostly.

BE11:24am

So ..... what's left to do? Here's a market share chart from UBS.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

BE11:25am

Which combination makes sense from here? Skybet is always rumoured as a consolidator but that never seems to come to anything .....

BE11:26am

Bet365 is .... best not discussed in detail here.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

So, that leaves a Paddy Power and William Hill merger?

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 299.30, up 7.9 (+2.71%), High: 304.10, Low: 296.30, Volume: 1.89m
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 8,445, down 25 (-0.30%), High: 8,515, Low: 8,400, Volume: 31.38k
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Which would of course require quite a few shop disposals, though perhaps not as many as you might initially assume.

BE11:27am

Anyway, enough bookies.

undefined
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Oh! Should note that Ladbrokes was mentioned in passing yesterday because of the Goldman M&A basket, which I'll now hoof up in readable form.

BE11:28am

M&A potenial of 15% or more get ranked 1 or 2, to remind.

BE11:28am

11:28 am
BE11:28am

BE11:29am

BE11:29am

One interesting name to note among those is Temenos, the Swiss banking software thing.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Which is being crawled over by all the punters right now.

BE11:29am

And to be clear, we don't know why.

BE11:29am

The first thing to say about Temenos is that it's been a pretty extraordinary performer this year.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

As in:

BE11:30am

BE11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live. FT Alphaville's daily this thing.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Lots of people excited about that. Significant proof-of-concept type contract win with Brazil's Itaú Unibanco earlier in the month.

BE11:31am

Now, the rally means Temenos is already pretty seriously expensive -- albeit not out of line with the likes of Workday and Altassian.

BE11:31am

Chart from Vontobel.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

BE11:32am

The idea for Temenos M&A, it would seem, is that it could be a strategic purchase. Its ability to land very large deals in the banking world would be useful for one of the biggies.

BE11:32am

The punters are therefore looking towards the very top tier of software companies. Microsoft, Oracle, SAP, Symantec ... that kind of bracket.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Are the punters right, though? Dunno. Absolutely no idea.

undefined
BE11:34am

And, almost as if we've thought about it, there's also Virgin Money. Which is tangentially a Temenos story.

11:34 am
Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 267.40, up 1.6 (+0.60%), High: 267.80, Low: 260.20, Volume: 585.25k
BE11:35am

Credit Suisse becoming less keen, in part because Virgin's gone for something called 10x Future Technologies for its back office tech.

BE11:36am

[U]sing the technology to replace the old systems of the existing bank would be a more ambitious and complex project, and 10x Technologies (VM's partner) may not necessarily have significant experience with such 'migration' projects – in fact VM is its first commercial client.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

More generally, it's a "margins look a bit tight, digital looks a bit never-never" thing.

BE11:38am

We remain cautious about the margin outlook despite VM guiding to a lower 'Banking NIM' for FY18 vs FY17 (CSe 172/165/162bps for 17/18/19). We think there are constraints on deposit and mortgage pricing, and we expect a neutral mix benefit from credit cards (vs c10bps/4bps in FY16/17). Our 18/19E earnings changes reflect weaker margins and growth and, for 19E, £35m higher costs associated with the digital bank.

BE11:38am

Full pay-off from the digital bank (VMDB) looks distant (and uncertain). We do not expect a clearer roadmap to emerge until FY19 or beyond (with implementation even later), on how the project could fully digitalise the existing bank to achieve material cost savings. We think upside risk from cheaper deposits is more modest in the near term – attracting £1bn more vs our base case estimates by 19E benefits Group NIM by c0.9bp.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Though that's all set against the risk of VM being taken private, like all the other challenger banks that were floated and then taken private shortly after.

BE11:39am

We believe VM has the potential to be attractive to a large and well-resourced private investor with a longer-term investment horizon:
■ Current valuations of c7x 17/18E earnings are low and, as we argued, VM has the potential to be a first-mover in becoming a 'front-to-back' digital organisation. If successfully implemented, this arguably leaves the prospective investor with a differentiated asset.
■ We note that previous acquisition activity in the sector has seen offer prices around 10x 12-month forward consensus earnings (see Figure 5), which would imply c50% potential upside to VM's current share price.
■ VM's current market capitalisation is c£1.2bn, and the Virgin Group, which controls 35% of the company, has worked previously with the likes of US private equity investor
Wilbur Ross1 (who has since divested his shares in VM).
■ However, we note this is a purely theoretical scenario at this point, and we think that any such investor would have to be comfortable with the technological feasibility of a 'front-to-back' digital VM.

BE11:40am

That's the gist of that.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:41am

Comments very slow today. I assume you're all still reading the Wikipedia page on Crispr.

BE11:41am

In terms of what has been mentioned, there's Xafinity.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Buying Punter Southall to pretty much double its revenue base.

BE11:42am

Price of £153m, or 11.3x earnings.

BE11:42am

Financed by £92m cash +£80m of new debt at c 1.75% over LIBOR.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Nothing in there on synergies whatsoever. But apparently they'll have two overlapping offices of the 15 in the enlarged group, so it's not hard to guess what happens next.

BE11:44am

Jeremy Grime of Finncap says .......

BE11:44am

Currently Xafinity trades on an EV multiple of 14.9X EBIT. Punter Southall is being acquired on a multiple of 11.3X. Prof forma EV multiple looks like 13.35X. So c 10% enhancement at the EV level. Increased gearing is likely to increase this at the PE level.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

I believe the synergy is expected to be revenue synergy as a result of becoming a challenger to the big 3 consultants in the market. The big 3 have revenues of c £300-£400m each and this new challenger has revenues of c £110m. So that’s a good story for the future which is not where the compny is today having delivered 2% growth. The valuation seems to be pricing in upside which is yet to be delivered and in view of the CMA referral perhaps can’t be relied on. That looks up with events to me.

BE11:45am

(@Tom: me too! That, however, would demand preparation.)

BE11:46am

And here's Liberum.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

The combination of the ninth (Xafinity) and eleventh (Punter Southall) player in the UK pension consultant market is expected to result in the creation of the largest pure-play consultant. This move is anticipated to provide the enlarged group with a stronger platform from which to access the large scale actuarial and administration markets. Management has also indicated that the deal will put the company in a stronger position to benefit from the CMA’s review into the investment consultant market's structure, which could see pressure on the ‘Big 3’ to concede market share.

BE11:46am

Total revenues of the businesses being acquired in the 12 months to December 2016 was £51.0m, which along with administration expenses of £40.4m resulted in an operating profit of £10.6m being generated. Of the reported administration costs, £4.3m relate to Central Business Unit charges which are not expected to recur under the new structure. Instead Xafinity has entered into a Transitional Service Agreement with Punter Southall Group for a maximum term of two years at a cost of up to £2.1m per annum. This agreement will provide Xafinity with the required IT, HR, finance and legal and compliance services to help minimise any operational disruption during the separation phase.

On this point management has indicated that a detailed plan for the separation is expected to be delivered within four months of the deal completing. As part of this plan and the group’s broader integration initiatives, an additional net cost of £4m is expected to be incurred by Xafinity over a 27 month period. Approximately two thirds of this is expected to be one-off in nature and should ensure that the enlarged group is adequately resourced to deliver on its long-term growth plans.

Based on this cost profile, management has indicated that it anticipates the deal being EPS enhancing in the year to 31 March 2019 and materially earnings enhancing thereafter. Leverage (net debt to EBITDA) for the enlarged group is expected to be below 2.0x on completion.

BE11:47am

Completion date, January 2018.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Assuming the regulators don't throw sand into the wheels.

undefined
BE11:49am

Whitbread? Certainly.

11:49 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,925, down 65 (-1.63%), High: 4,055, Low: 3,896, Volume: 380.68k
BE11:49am

.... though the story writes itself, really, as we've written it countless times before.

BE11:51am

As in, Whitbread trades at a discount to its SOTP if you stick Costa on a Starbucks rating and Premier Inn on a Holiday Inn rating and also do a giant sale and leaseback of property but management doesn't really fancy any of this in part because they see value to sticking a Beefeater pub on their middle-of-nowhere hotels.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

What's changed as of yesterday is Sachem Head turning up on the register ......

BE11:52am

.... which is an occasional activist rather than a pain-in-the-arse in the style of Elliott.

BE11:52am

Autodesk, I think, is the one they're best known for. But they're also in Shire in the UK, and haven't done much.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Here's some Numis.

BE11:53am

In 2013 when JAB acquired DE Master Blenders and Peet’s coffee it was clear that there could be further consolidation in the fragmented coffee market. At that time Costa had grown EBIT at a 5y CAGR of 25% and was achieving lfl sales growth in the UK of 5%. The difficulty now is that growth has slowed and the potential to achieve such high multiples on a spin-off may have reduced with it. In 1H18 Costa’s EBIT was flat and we forecast the same for FY18 as a whole. Lfl sales growth has been uneven in recent quarters: in the 3m to Feb 17 lfls fell by -0.8% and in the most recent quarter growth was only 0.1%. Currently Costa's international business makes an EBIT of only c£7m (LTM) and margin of 4.4%, with scope to improve as investments in China mature.

BE11:53am

Notwithstanding these caveats, the sum of parts argument still has some credibility in our view. We note that Starbucks trades on a 2018 EV/EBITDA of 14.3x (Bloomerg estimates) and M&A in the sector has been at multiples over 15x. In contrast, WTB as a group trades on a FY19 EBITDA multiple of 8.8x and P/E of 15.0x, well below its cyclical high of 26x. We believe this partly reflects concerns on the UK consumer environment and is a response to a slowdown in EPS growth.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Valuation implications: Note that each 1x EBITDA turn for Costa is £243m of equity value or 133p per share (3.5%). Assuming that hotels/restaurants continue to trade on c.9x but Costa is valued at 14x EBITDA would add £1.2bn to fair value or 670p (17% vs yesterday’s opening price of 3710p). The counter-argument is that the fundamental outlook remains weak and the combination of lfl sales growth of 1.7% (NUMe for FY18) and rising cost inflation will limit earnings growth to less than 3% this year.

BE11:55am

And Canaccord.

BE11:55am

The interest in Sachem Head revolves round the identity of its CEO, Scott Ferguson who previously worked with renown Bill Ackman at Pershing. Sachem Head has not made its intentions clear but we believe it must have been attracted by the 40% decline in Whitbread's share price since its 2015 high-water mark and by the restructuring opportunities to create value.
Premier Inn and Costa Coffee are uneasy bed-fellows as there are no material synergies between the businesses and perhaps the uncharitable view is that it is not always apparent what value the PLC adds to its constituents. De-merger talk had died down in recent years as new(ish) CEO Alison Brittain echoed chairman Richard Baker's stance that a demerger is not on the agenda.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

For Whitbread the opportunity is to turn interesting international bridgeheads into material growth opportunities for both Premier Inn and Costa Coffee. For Premier Inn the focus is on Germany and for Costa Coffee the focus is China.
Whitbread is also under-leveraged with net debt/EBITDA of just 1.1x for FY18E. The position of the Whitbread pension trustees potentially adds a complication to any break- up as the FY17 deficit was c.£400m with Whitbread paying £95m pa in contributions.

BE11:55am

Our 4500p target price remains based on DCF and Quest® valuations. It is also equivalent to c17.5x PE for FY18E falling to 16.3x the following year which is marginally above the average for the last five and ten years. We expect Whitbread to deliver a 6% EPS CAGR to 2020E. At yesterday's close it was trading on a P/E of 15.6x for FY18E falling to 14.6x for FY19E. It is on an EV/EBITDA of 10.4x falling to 9.8x for the same
periods.

BE11:56am

Note, incidentally, the Whitbread tick chart yesterday.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

The market was incredibly slow to notice the Sachem Head stake announcement, which I think dropped at about 1.30pm.

BE11:57am

And the wires didn't even flash it until more than an hour later, seemingly having been alerted by the share price move.

BE11:58am

I've written in the past about how investors are bad at spotting activists landing on the register with specific reference to Rolls-Royce: https://www.ft.com...-bbd1-b37bc06f590c

11:59 am
BE11:59am

I blame the diffusion of regulatory news services on that one. But maybe it's that we're just getting extremely bad, or lazy, at reading the tape.

BE11:59am

"If it's interesting, the machines will catch it." Aye, well maybe they won't.

undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Okay, that brief pause was while I followed a link to a Brexit story that ended up on The Sun website ......

BE12:05pm

.... which then killed my browser by showing a tonne of junk about the death of some lady who did grumble flicks.

BE12:05pm

The story seems to be about meetings next week. The Brexit one, I mean, not the other one.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

In terms of Pearson, mostly just dollar I think.

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 737.50, up 16.5 (+2.29%), High: 743.00, Low: 721.00, Volume: 1.82m
BE12:06pm

JP Morgan has its 2018 media outlook out, which involves a change of analyst to Daniel Kervan, but he remains neutral.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

We expect ad momentum to improve supported by product launches, tech advertisers, quadrennial events and digital growth. In our view, FMCGs need to invest more on traditional advertising to defend existing brands and on digital to launch new products given increasing competition & slowing organic growth. In the medium term, advertising should see structural growth as digital / performance growth more than offsets print declines.

BE12:07pm

Also likes free-to-air.

BE12:07pm

Valuations are cheap, expectations are low, structural
concerns are overstated & new growth opportunities overlooked. While we see scope for a further rally into year-end, the “slowdown” phase of the economic cycle represents a headwind for performance & suggests a selective approach. Pro7 is our key pick. We are also OW ITV and RTL.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Key picks: Vivendi, Pro7, eOne, UBM, Just Eat and Delivery Hero.

undefined
BE12:09pm

Okay, we're done. Thanks for joining. Hope it's been more fun for you than it has for me.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.

BE11:30am

Which is largely on the back of WealthSuite. A cloud-compatible front-plus-back office suite of stuff for private banking, portfolio management, analytics, that kind of thing.
